I think that the Bush Administration thought they had a great idea and I mean the title "No Child Left Behind" sounds great too, but the real title should be "No Child Left Untested". I don't think standarized testing is the answer and I also disagree with a lot of the legislation in No Child Left Behind because it puts all of the accountability on the teacher and doesn't consider the fact that a teacher can be the most amazing incredible teacher there is, but there are some kids who just aren't motivated and maybe that has to do with parents, maybe it just has to do with the individual child, but whatever it is, teachers should not be held 100% accountable for a child's low test score on standardized testing. 
 
 I do believe we need some sort of reform, but I don't think standardized testing is the answer. In addition to that not every child is the same. Standardized testing pretty much says that "one test fits all". However, even though we try to mainstream kids and say that they all fit into one test, that simply is not true. 
 
 I am a middle school science teacher, however because I have a special knack at helping out kids who are in resource and ESL. I have a lot of students who aren't up to reading level or who don't understand the test. A lot of them need special accomodations, but even with those special accomodations it doesn't mean they have the same advantage as the other kids I teach. Honestly in some ways I want to tell the resource teachers or the ESL teachers to stop giving me so many of their kids because in reality they bring down my test scores and with NCLB legislation, if my test scores don't reach a certain proficiency level by 2012 then I'm in danger of losing my job. I take the ESL and resource kids because I care and I want them to feel like they are apart of a normal classroom. I want them to feel included with the other kids who aren't in resource or ESL, but it does bring down my scores.
